J. H. U. QUINT
DOWNS DELAWARE
Jays Take Third Victory by
Score of 34-24
DEBUSKEY HIGH SCORER
Sterling Attack Centers on
Star Center and Stude
The Johns Hopkins University
basketball team came out on top by
a wide margin in the game against
Delaware University. The game,
making the third victory for the
Blue Jays this season, was played at
Carlin's Park last Saturday a fternoon. The final score was Hopkins
34, Delaware 24.
Debuskey Scores 16 Points

Delaware's defense was broken
up from the start of the game when
Hopkins' attack, led by Gene Debuskey brought the ball under the
basket four times for tries for field
goals. Although Debuskey missed
all four shots it seemed to be all he
needed to get his eye on the basket.
from then on the Hopkins' center,
time and again, threw field goals
from all sorts of positions. He also
made two out of four foul shots,
which, together with his seven field
goals, gave him a total of 16 points
for the high scorer.

Price 5 Cents

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 21, 1930

Vol. XXXIV, No. 26

FENCING TEAM HOLDS
MEETING TODAY
The recently formed Fencing Club will meet in the
south loft of Gilman Hall, at
12.20 P. M. today. Much
equipment has been purchased
and Club officials plan to
go ahead with the various activities of the organization.
The ten active members registered at present declare that
they will give fundamental instruction in dwelling to anyone who desires to become a
member of the organization.

UNIQUE OFFER IS MADE TO
GRADUATING CHEM STUDENTS
Chemistry students graduating
this June, have received an offer
of a position which is decidedly
unique. Bowdoin College is looking
for a teacher who is evidently to
be a cross between Einstein and
the late Wayne B. Wheeler. The
successful applicant must not only
teach two courses in chemistry,
answer all questions from undergraduates in other chemistry courses
but he also must belong to the Prohibition enforcement army. Says the
letter which extends the offer, "It
is quite important that the man we
get should be able to get on with
undergraduates and have sufficient
common sense to prevent him from
the indescretion of diverting laboratory alcohol into unscientific channels." Evidently Bowdoin chemists
are skilled in the art of manufacturing synthetic gin out of laboratory alcohol. In that case, we should
like to have the proper instructions,
for so far we have always hesitated
to use our alcohol here for fear of
the ruinous effects of the denaturant
on our internal apparatus. There
have been times when some of our
luckier students have managed to
get pure alcohol and we recall one
particular quantitative analyst of
last year who succeeded quite well
in the concocting of rather good

synthetic gin. At least it was enough
to keep him in a "happy" mood for
several days.
We haven't discovered yet,
whether or not the professor in
charge of the course had any hand
in diverting this alcohol into "unscientific channels" nor did Ile ever
show the effects of having shared
in the enjoyment of the finished
product.
Bowdoin, incidently, expects this
new instructor to be a "walking
text-book, for he is to answer any
and all questions which the chemistry students may ask him. We wonder what he is supposed to do if
one of his students should ask him
how to make gin. In his spare time,
the instructor is to do research
work, but we should imagine that
with his duties as a prohibition
agent, he'll have very little time to
investigate anything but ways and
means of preventing drunkenness among the undergraduates.
For all these multifarious duties,
the munificent salary of $2,000 is
offered, though such a man would
obviously be worth $20,000. At any
rate, Hopkins has a rare opportunity
this offer to materially aid the
cause of prohibition while teaching

BALTIMORE AND JAYS
TO MEET FRIDAY
Johns Hopkins University
will play the University of
Baltimore this Friday night,
according to Jack Purcell,
manager of the Jay five.
The match was scheduled
recently and, accordingly, does
not appear on the season schedule: Baltimore has an excellent outfit this year and fans
are looking forward to the
fracas. The opponents of the
Jays lost to Washington College by only one point and
defeated Loyola.
The time of the game is
announced as nine o'clock
and will be staged at Carlins.

Mid-Season Form

when the Jay five will meet the

work against St. John's last Wednesday can be accepted as a criterion. Georgetown lists among its

'Institutions which apparently satisfy the first need exist in considerable number today. Some of our Eastern universities serve the
purpose admirably. There are now and always will be, I suppose, institutions where the 'drifters' will find a place. In fact, most collegiate
institutions today are organized on a basis that meets their needs. At
Hopkins we are saying that the bright boy shall also have his chance.
The type of institution that meets his needs is rare. Frankly, Hopkins
is preparing to meet this need."
We feel that the above paragraphs constitute a full and adequate
explanation of the so-called new plan. We are all familiar with the
idle type of undergraduate and the great majority of us are "drifters!"
It is quite clear that the "liberal education" offered at most universities, including the undergraduate department at Hopkins, conforms
ideally to the needs of these men. It is equally clear that a young
man who has decided on a particular line of scholarly work and who
has the intelligence to do well in his chosen branch is wasting a great
deal of time in pursuing the academic course. The new plan affords
a splendid opportunity to such men. It is quite necessary to have colIeges where the "drifter" may find his place, but the point made by
Dean Berry is that there are an abundance of such institutions in this
country, but that there are few for the "bright boy."
Another comment of Dean Berry offers a field for a little introspection—an exercise which is but little practical by the average college
student. He says, "Roughly speaking, there are three types of brains—
the sieve-like, the sponge-like and the tool-like brain. The sieve brain
retains very little; only a modicum of what passes through sticks. The
student with the sieve brain ought not to go beyond the grade school.
The sponge brain absorbs and retains whatever is put in—and what
goes in is not changed by criticism and reflection. Perhaps the student
with the sponge-like brain should be put through high school. Certainly, he should not be admitted to a first-rate collegiate institution.
The student with the tool-like brain, which enables him to inquire and
investigate for himself—the brain that is capable of acquiring a point
of view, of criticism and of holding judgment in reserve—that is the
only type of student who should be admitted to a first-rate collegiate
institution."
The News-Letter regrets to announce the resignations of Stewart
L.:Smith and Lewis Danziger from the editorial staff.

At Willamette University a suggestion was made to give a dance
for the benefit of injured football
players. According to the Willamette Collegian the suggestion was

this dance, methinks, football should
be abolished at Willamette.

function in the desired manner. Apparently Alfred University does not
have the honor system.

GRADUATE STUDENTS
TO HOLD TEA DANCE
Next Thursday the Graduate Students will hold another
of their tea-dances in Levering Hall, at 4 P. M., the expenses will be 50 cents per
person or $1.00 per couple.
The dances so far this year
have been successful, it was
stated, and those in charge expect that this one will be as
much, or more so, than the
others.
The time of the dance has
been changed from 5 to 4
o'clock.

Long Island University was recently the victor in a football game
by the score of 22 to 11. This
game was the first one to be played
in the East under the system of
marking now being advocated. By
this system one point is given for
each first down. Six points are
given, as always, for a touchdown.
No extra point is given after the
touchdown. This seems to be more
representative of the power of each
team.

Dr. Zeuch Will
Address Club

"Workers Education at Commonwealth" will be the title of an address to be delivered before the
Liberal Club on Friday, January
24, by Dr. William E. Zeuch,
founder and president of Commonwealth College, Mena, Arkansas.
Commonwealth College is a very
interesting experiment in labor education. It was organized in 1923 to
provide working men and women
with an opportunity to secure an
education and support themselves
at the same time. Both students and
faculty spend four hours daily in
agricultural and other work about
the college, besides attending
courses. The institution is non-sectarian, and sponsors no particular
political or economic creed.
Before Dr. Zeuch's talk, which
will begin at 1 P. M., the Liberal
Club will hold a luncheon in his
honor. The luncheon will be held at
12.30, in Room C. Levering Hall,
and will cost 50 cents. Reservations
can be made by sending a note to
Miss Roberta White, Psychology
Laboratory, by Thursday.

DOWNS DELAWARE
Jays Take Third Victory by

DEBUSKEY HIGH SCORER
Sterling Attack Centers on
Star Center and Stude
The Johns Hopkins University
basketball team came out on top by
a wide margin in the game against
Delaware University. The game,
making the third victory for the
Blue Jays this season, was played at
Carlin's Park last Saturday a fternoon. The final score was Hopkins
34, Delaware 24.
Debuskey Scores 16 Points

Delaware's defense was broken
up from the start of the game when
Hopkins' attack, led by Gene Debuskey brought the ball under the
basket four times for tries for field
goals. Although Debuskey missed
all four shots it seemed to be all he
needed to get his eye on the basket.
from then on the Hopkins' center,
time and again, threw field goals
from all sorts of positions. He also
made two out of four foul shots,
which, together with his seven field
goals, gave him a total of 16 points
for the high scorer.

UNIQUE OFFER IS MADE TO
GRADUATING CHEM STUDENTS
Chemistry students graduating
this June, have received an offer
of a position which is decidedly
unique. Bowdoin College is looking
for a teacher who is evidently to
be a cross between Einstein and
the late Wayne B. Wheeler. The
successful applicant must not only
teach two courses in chemistry,
answer all questions from undergraduates in other chemistry courses
but he also must belong to the Prohibition enforcement army. Says the
letter which extends the offer, "It
is quite important that the man we
get should be able to get on with
undergraduates and have sufficient
common sense to prevent him from
the indescretion of diverting laboratory alcohol into unscientific channels." Evidently Bowdoin chemists
are skilled in the art of manufacturing synthetic gin out of laboratory alcohol. In that case, we should
like to have the proper instructions,
for so far we have always hesitated
to use our alcohol here for fear of
the ruinous effects of the denaturant
on our internal apparatus. There
have been times when some of our
luckier students have managed to
get pure alcohol and we recall one
particular quantitative analyst of
last year who succeeded quite well
in the concocting of rather good

synthetic gin. At least it was enough
to keep him in a "happy" mood for
several days.
We haven't discovered yet,
whether or not the professor in
charge of the course had any hand
in diverting this alcohol into "unscientific channels" nor did Ile ever
show the effects of having shared
in the enjoyment of the finished
product.
Bowdoin, incidently, expects this
new instructor to be a "walking
text-book, for he is to answer any
and all questions which the chemistry students may ask him. We wonder what he is supposed to do if
one of his students should ask him
how to make gin. In his spare time,
the instructor is to do research
work, but we should imagine that
with his duties as a prohibition
agent, he'll have very little time to
investigate anything but ways and
means of preventing drunkenness among the undergraduates.
For all these multifarious duties,
the munificent salary of $2,000 is
offered, though such a man would
obviously be worth $20,000. At any
rate, Hopkins has a rare opportunity
this offer to materially aid the
cause of prohibition while teaching

and will be staged at Carlins.

'Institutions which apparently satisfy the first need exist in considerable number today. Some of our Eastern universities serve the
purpose admirably. There are now and always will be, I suppose, institutions where the 'drifters' will find a place. In fact, most collegiate
institutions today are organized on a basis that meets their needs. At
Hopkins we are saying that the bright boy shall also have his chance.
The type of institution that meets his needs is rare. Frankly, Hopkins
is preparing to meet this need."
We feel that the above paragraphs constitute a full and adequate
explanation of the so-called new plan. We are all familiar with the
idle type of undergraduate and the great majority of us are "drifters!"
It is quite clear that the "liberal education" offered at most universities, including the undergraduate department at Hopkins, conforms
ideally to the needs of these men. It is equally clear that a young
man who has decided on a particular line of scholarly work and who
has the intelligence to do well in his chosen branch is wasting a great
deal of time in pursuing the academic course. The new plan affords
a splendid opportunity to such men. It is quite necessary to have colIeges where the "drifter" may find his place, but the point made by
Dean Berry is that there are an abundance of such institutions in this
country, but that there are few for the "bright boy."
Another comment of Dean Berry offers a field for a little introspection—an exercise which is but little practical by the average college
student. He says, "Roughly speaking, there are three types of brains—
the sieve-like, the sponge-like and the tool-like brain. The sieve brain
retains very little; only a modicum of what passes through sticks. The
student with the sieve brain ought not to go beyond the grade school.
The sponge brain absorbs and retains whatever is put in—and what
goes in is not changed by criticism and reflection. Perhaps the student
with the sponge-like brain should be put through high school. Certainly, he should not be admitted to a first-rate collegiate institution.
The student with the tool-like brain, which enables him to inquire and
investigate for himself—the brain that is capable of acquiring a point
of view, of criticism and of holding judgment in reserve—that is the
only type of student who should be admitted to a first-rate collegiate
institution."

At Willamette University a suggestion was made to give a dance
for the benefit of injured football
players. According to the Willamette Collegian the suggestion was
not met with approval. If there are
rnough players injured to call for
this dance, methinks, football should
be abolished at Willamette.

An editorial in the paper of Alfred University, discusses the honor
system. Some time ago, it appears,
a vote was taken there among the
students of an Economic Life Class.
By this vote the system fails to
function in the desired manner. Apparently Alfred University does not
have the honor system.

words are the crying need of the
nation today. We think that if the
vocabulary of a college student was
as complete in all lines as it is in
that, he might get better English
!narks.

GRADUATE STUDENTS
TO HOLD TEA DANCE
Next Thursday the Graduate Students will hold another
of their tea-dances in Levering Hall, at 4 P. M., the expenses will be 50 cents per
person or $1.00 per couple.
The dances so far this year
have been successful, it was
stated, and those in charge expect that this one will be as
much, or more so, than the
others.
The time of the dance has
been changed from 5 to 4
o'clock.

Long Island University was recently the victor in a football game
by the score of 22 to 11. This
game was the first one to be played
in the East under the system of
marking now being advocated. By
this system one point is given for
each first down. Six points are
given, as always, for a touchdown.
No extra point is given after the
touchdown. This seems to be more
representative of the power of each
team.

"Workers Education at Commonwealth" will be the title of an address to be delivered before the
Liberal Club on Friday, January
24, by Dr. William E. Zeuch,
founder and president of Commonwealth College, Mena, Arkansas.
Commonwealth College is a very
interesting experiment in labor education. It was organized in 1923 to
provide working men and women
with an opportunity to secure an
education and support themselves
at the same time. Both students and
faculty spend four hours daily in
agricultural and other work about
the college, besides attending
courses. The institution is non-sectarian, and sponsors no particular
political or economic creed.
Before Dr. Zeuch's talk, which
will begin at 1 P. M., the Liberal
Club will hold a luncheon in his
honor. The luncheon will be held at
12.30, in Room C. Levering Hall,
and will cost 50 cents. Reservations
can be made by sending a note to
Miss Roberta White, Psychology
Laboratory, by Thursday.
